page.title: 06What are our surroundings ?
page.content: The landscape is{flat, open farmland} with occasional{wooded areas.}A{levee} protects Fiskerton and Morton from the floodwaters of the{River Trent.} Most buildings are of red brick. There are some imposing early 19th century houses facing the river at Fiskerton. Nearby,{Fiskerton Mill,}a four-storeyed brick building, stands astride the Halloughton Dumble. {Fiskerton Methodist Church,}an unsophisticated edifice built in 1807, is probably the oldest in the County. {Fiskerton Station,}a delightful little cottage ornee, was built in 1849 for the Midland railway. The small, red brick{Morton Church,}built in 1756, has round-headed windows, a shallow aspidal sanctuary and an embattled tower.{Rolleston Church}with its tall pinnacle has two spectacular arcades and beautiful 17th century woodwork.
